title: 106_hr3892
content:
The "Safe and Healthy Oceanic Recovery and Enhancement Act" allows for the transfer of authority to issue permits for the transportation of dredged material for ocean dumping. The authority to issue permits for transporting dredged material for ocean dumping is transferred from the Secretary of the Army to the Commission on Dredge Material Policy. Any references to this authority now refer to the Commission. The Commission may exercise these authorities as needed. The Commission can use all authorities previously held by the Secretary of the Army for the transferred functions. All legal documents issued by the Secretary of the Army or other officials in relation to the transferred authority remain in effect. The transferred authorities shall remain in effect until modified or revoked by the President, the Commission, a court, or operation of law. This section does not affect pending proceedings or applications for benefits, services, licenses, permits, certificates, or financial assistance related to the transferred authority. Such proceedings and applications will continue as usual. Orders issued in proceedings and appeals will continue until modified or revoked by authorized officials or by a court. This section does not impact ongoing suits, which will proceed as usual. (4) Nonabatement of actions.--Suits, actions, or proceedings initiated by or against an individual in their official capacity as an officer or employee responsible for transferred authorities will not be affected by this Act.
(5) Continuance of suits.--If a government officer involved in a suit has their authority transferred to another officer or office, the suit will continue with the new officer or office head as a party. The Act specifies that statutory requirements for notice, hearings, and administrative or judicial review apply to the Commission's exercise of transferred authority. Personnel, property, records, and funds related to transferred authorities will be available to the Commission as directed by the Director of the Office of Management and Budget. The Commission may delegate authorities transferred to officers and employees as necessary. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget will make determinations regarding transferred authority. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget may make determinations and dispositions related to the authority transferred under this section, including personnel, assets, liabilities, grants, contracts, and funds. Termination of entities and additional measures may also be provided as necessary. The Act allows for further measures and dispositions to be taken as necessary. Existing funds for terminated functions will remain available for related expenses. Conforming amendments are made to the Marine Protection, Research, and Sanctuaries Act of 1972. Conforming amendments are made to the Marine Protection, Research, and Sanctuaries Act of 1972. In section 106(d)(2)(C) (33 U.S.C. 1416(d)(2)(C)), the term "Commission" is inserted. In section 103 (33 U.S.C. 1413), the section heading is replaced with new text. Establishment of Commission on Dredge Material Policy under Marine Protection, Research, and Sanctuaries Act of 1972. Commission duties include carrying out responsibilities under the Act. Membership details are outlined for the Commission. The Commission on Dredge Material Policy under the Marine Protection, Research, and Sanctuaries Act of 1972 is composed of 16 members appointed by the President with Senate approval. Members are selected based on their expertise in ocean and dredging activities, representing various sectors. The Commission's membership is geographically balanced for expertise. The Commission on Dredge Material Policy has 16 members appointed by the President with Senate approval. Members are chosen based on expertise in ocean and dredging activities, representing different sectors. The appointment process includes recommendations from Senate and House leaders for a balanced representation. The Commission on Dredge Material Policy has 16 members appointed by the President with Senate approval. Members serve 4-year terms, with initial appointees serving varying term lengths. The Commission on Dredge Material Policy has 16 members appointed by the President with Senate approval. Members serve 4-year terms, with initial appointees serving varying term lengths. Members are entitled to receive basic pay at the rate of grade GS-4 of the General Schedule for each day of duty and travel expenses. Vacancies are filled in the same manner as the original appointment. The Commission on Dredge Material Policy consists of 16 members appointed by the President with Senate approval. Members receive travel expenses and per diem in lieu of subsistence. A majority of members constitute a quorum, with the Chairperson elected by the members for a 2-year term. Meetings are called by the Chairperson or majority of members, with the first meeting within 30 days of member appointments. The Commission on Dredge Material Policy can appoint staff and consultants as needed. Federal agencies can also provide personnel to assist the Commission. The Commission has powers outlined in Section 405. The Commission on Dredge Material Policy has the authority to hold hearings, gather evidence, and obtain information from government agencies. Members and agents can take actions authorized by the Commission. The Commission can also use the United States mails and request administrative support services. The Commission on Dredge Material Policy can request administrative support services from the Administrator of General Services on a reimbursable basis. Additionally, the Commission has the authority to contract with government and private agencies for supplies and services.
